summary: Aiken State Park - Jungle Nature Trail
description:
Join us on this 2.7-mile out-and-back trail near Windsor, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through April. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Please RSVP below.

Join us for our official launch and first event at Sesquicentennial State Park on this 4.6-mile loop trail near State Park, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 31 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.
location: 9564 Two Notch Rd, Columbia, SC 29223, USA

description:
Head out on this 3.0-mile out-and-back trail near Hopkins, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 52 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.Â 

Â This trail leaves from the Harry Hampton Visitor Center and follows the Bluff Trail and Caroline Sims Trail to Wise Lake and back. The trail takes you through a dense forest. Depending on the time of year, the trail can get very muddy, so wearing appropriate footwear is recommended. Be sure to bring bug spray, because mosquitoes are common on this trail. This is a great trail for viewing wildlife.

Please RSVP below so we can get a headcount!

summary: Paris Mountain State Park - Sulphur Springs Trail
description: Check out this 4.0-mile loop trail near Greenville, South Carolina. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 51 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, mountain biking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.The trail follows a creek and offers stunning views of cascades and a lake. Though the first mile has some inclines, the rest of the trail is relatively easy. The trail is well-maintained and mostly shaded. However, the trailhead is quite popular, so it's recommended to start early. Overall, this is a fantastic trail with a few sneaky uphill portions.

summary: Dreher Island State Park - Little Gap Trail
description: Get to know this 2.3-mile loop trail near Prosperity, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 49 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.Starting from the kiosk on Red Maple Drive, the Little Gap Trail is the most strenuous of the three trails in the park. Following the trail markers on the trees, you will wander up and down through a thick forest of pines and hardwoods, which is home to a number of animals and birds. You may also be lucky enough to sight a bald eagle that nests in this area. Some interesting white rocks line the trail in spots as you make a loop at the end of the peninsula.

Check out this 2.5-mile loop trail near Pelion, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 56 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.This route offers a picturesque journey through a breathtaking forest and leads to a magnificent waterfall. However, the trail is not clearly marked, and there are many misleading social trails. The path around Little Peachtree Rock can be particularly challenging to navigate. It is recommended to download the offline map to assist with directions.

Check out this 5.7-mile loop trail near Edgefield, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 5 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, mountain biking, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.
location: Horn Creek Trail Trailhead, State Hwy S-19-392, Edgefield, SC 29824

description: Get to know this 4.3-mile out-and-back trail near Edisto Island, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 15 min to complete. This trail is great for camping, hiking, and mountain biking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are September through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.This is a lovely wide soft sandy trail with several boardwalks that meanders through the trees and marsh.
location: 8377 State Cabin Rd, Edisto Island, SC 29438, USA

description: Discover this 2.1-mile loop trail near Hopkins, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 37 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.This trail leaves from the Longleaf Campground, and follows the longleaf trail to the Bluff Trail. Follow the Bluff Trail as it loops through dense forest. The trail follows a wooden boardwalk most of the way is well-maintained and well-marked. Keep an eye out for birds and other wildlife. Be sure to bring bug spray, as mosquitoes are common in this area.
location: Longleaf Trail, 201 National Park Rd, Hopkins, SC 29061, USA

summary: Kings Mountain State Park - Kings Mountain Nature Trail
description: Check out this 8.9-mile out-and-back trail near Grover, North Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 21 min to complete. This is a popular trail for camping, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas.At lower elevations the trail runs alongside clear babbling streams surrounded by dense forest cover, an abundance of mountain laurel, and thick carpets of ferns. At higher elevations the tree cover is more sparse and the trail becomes much rockier. There is a 1 mile roundtrip spur trail that leads to the top of Browns Mountain (1,045 feet) and a campsite at Garner Creek.

Check out this 2.2-mile loop trail near West Columbia, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 40 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through October.Part of Cayce Riverwalk - This is the South End of Cayce Riverwalk and is mainly a loop around Congaree Creek with connection to the SCANA Parking and the Fort Congaree Entrance at the Cayce Tennis Courts.  It's a paved walkway great for runners, walkers, Cyclists, and nature lovers.  It's great for Wildflowers and Butterflies on Old State Road.  It connects to Cayce Riverwalk on the east end for a longer hike.

summary: Poinsett State Park - The Knot Splice Loop
description: Explore this 4.8-mile loop trail near Wedgefield, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 42 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are October through June. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.This is a fun hike in Poinsett State Park. It begins from the parking lot on Poinsett Park Road, where restrooms are available. This route uses several trails in the area. You'll want to have the trail map handy to ensure you are on the right path. Along the way, you will see trees with Spanish moss and the ruins of old barns. The path is well-shaded and padded with pine needles.
location: Rivian Waypoints, 6660 Poinsett Park Rd, Wedgefield, SC 29168

description: Discover this 4.6-mile out-and-back trail near Long Creek, South Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 10 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.The trailhead is located before the parking area, between two boulders. The trail is well-maintained and relatively easy to navigate, leading you to the breathtaking falls. Once you reach the Chattooga River, you'll find a beautiful beach where you can relax and enjoy the view. Be cautious as the trail becomes quite rocky as you approach the falls.
location: Turkey Ridge Rd, Long Creek, SC 29658

description: Get to know this 5.9-mile loop trail near Patrick, South Carolina. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 59 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are August through October.The Carolina Sandhills National Wildlife Refuge is one of the Southeastâ€™s premiere sites for viewing the rapidly diminishing longleaf pine/wiregrass ecosystem. Carolina Sandhills National Wildlife Refuge was created in 1939. Its establishing purpose was to provide habitat for migratory birds, to demonstrate sound management practices that enhance natural resource conservation, and to provide wildlife-oriented recreation opportunities. The land was badly eroded and very little wildlife was to be found when the refuge was purchased by the federal government under the provisions of the Resettlement Act. Efforts began immediately to restore this damaged, barren land to a healthy, rich habitat for the plants and animals that once lived here.
location: Tates Tower Trail, Tates Tower Trl, South Carolina 29101, USA
